title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" reserves funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, as well as for programs for Indian youth and national purposes. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" allocates funds for various purposes, including programs for Indian youth, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. The Secretary of the Interior reserves 1 percent of the funds for Indian youth programs and 0.2 percent for Native Hawaiian programs. State allotments are allocated by the Secretary among the States each fiscal year. The Secretary allocates state allotments each fiscal year based on school-aged population ratios and previous funding amounts under part A of title I. The Secretary allocates state allotments each fiscal year based on school-aged population ratios and previous funding amounts under part A of title I. The allotment to each State is determined by a formula that considers the amount received in the previous year and ensures that no State receives less than one-half of 1 percent of the total amount allotted to all States. The Secretary may reallot any amount to a State if it cannot be used within two years. The Secretary may reallot any amount of allotment to a State if it cannot be used within two years. Reallotments will be based on the same criteria as initial allotments. Definitions for this subsection include 'State' as each of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico, and 'local educational agency'. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term 'local educational agency' includes educational service agencies and consortia of such agencies. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. SEC. 4112 pertains to state applications. The chief executive officer of the State must submit an application to the Secretary to receive funding for drug and violence prevention programs, detailing coordination with other relevant Acts and the State's needs assessment results. The State's application for funding for drug and violence prevention programs must include results of the needs assessment, cooperation with national impact evaluation, and any other information required by the Secretary. The Secretary will use a peer review process for evaluation. The Secretary will conduct a national impact evaluation of programs required by section 4114(a) and use a peer review process for reviewing State applications. "SEC. 4113. STATE PROGRAMS." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants and contracts are exclusively for financing authorized programs. The allocated funds must be used by the State's chief executive officer for prevention programs focused on educating about the dangers of drug use and underage drinking. Grants and contracts are strictly for financing programs with a 'no use' antidrug message. The allocated funds must be used for prevention programs focused on educating about the dangers of drug use and underage drinking with a strict 'no use' antidrug message. Misuse of funds will result in penalties including forfeiture and reimbursement. Expenditures misuse results in penalties like forfeiture and reimbursement. Grants or contracts awarded under this subsection are subject to peer review. The chief executive officer of a State can directly carry out activities or use grants for law enforcement education partnerships. The chief executive officer can use funds to award grants for drug abuse and violence prevention activities through partnerships with law enforcement agencies and educational or community-based agencies. Prevention activities include programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education, Project Legal Lives, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals. District attorneys provide classroom instruction in the law and legal system, emphasizing interactive learning techniques like mock trial competitions, partnerships with child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs to combat violence in schools and submit findings to the President and Congress. Data collection will be done by the National Center for Education Statistics. The National Center for Education Statistics will collect data on violence in elementary and secondary schools to determine frequency, seriousness, and incidence. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations by January 1, 2000. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2000, with recommendations on data collected on violence in schools. States must also submit reports on their programs' implementation and effectiveness every third year. The CEO of the State must submit a report to the Secretary on the implementation and outcomes of State programs under section 4113, including data on drug use and violence by youth, every third year. The report must be in a specified form, based on ongoing evaluation activities, and made available to the public. "Programs for Native Hawaiians under SEC. 4114." The Secretary will provide grants or agreements to organizations serving Native Hawaiians recognized by the Governor of Hawaii to implement programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to the area before 1778.
